Award.AwardTitle: Tail-Biting Trellis Realizations for Block Codes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support research aimed at deepening our understanding of graphical representations of block codes. Such representations play a fundamental role in modern coding theory, where codes on graphs are used in order to employ iterative decoding algorithms. The powerful performance of these algorithms has led to a vivid interest in optimal graphical representations of codes. Tail-biting trellises form a particular type of such graphical models. This project focuses on studying the relation between various tail-biting trellis realizations of a given code, such as minimal realizations and irreducible ones, as well as on analyzing the performance of iterative decoding algorithms on these graphs.

Coding theory is at the interface of applied mathematics and engineering of communication systems. It deals with ensuring the integrity of data transmission via satellite, internet, cell phones etc. The basic idea is to preprocess the to-be-sent messages in such a way that, after sending, the receiver has a good chance to recover the original message from the received, and generally erroneous, message. The preprocessing is called the encoding, and the recovering process is the decoding. This award will support research geared toward optimal graphical representations of codes, which in turn is closely related to designing efficient decoding algorithms. The award will also support the graduate program at the University of Kentucky because two Ph.D. students will be involved in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project was part of mathematical coding theory. Coding theory is a modern area of applied algebra that aims at developing and analyzing mathematical tools for fast and reliable data transmission. When data are sent via, say, cell phone, internet, or digital broadcasting they usually suffer from outside errors and therefore are corrupted when they reach the receiver. Coding theory aims at encoding the data - by adding extra information - such that the receiver can recover the correct data from the erroneous ones. If the encoding is chosen wisely, transmission errors will most likely not destroy the whole data package and thus the receiver can decode the package and reconstruct the original data. All of this charges coding theory with the mathematical task of designing codes that can correct as many errors as possible - for various transmission settings - and such that error correction is fast.

The outcomes of this project contributed to both tasks. One subproject dealt with graphical representations of codes. Such representations afford iterative decoding algorithms (error correction) whose powerful performance have been known for quite some time. The project contributed to the size of certain graph types needed to represent a given code. The graph size is a fundamental parameter for the efficiency of the resulting decoding algorithm. Other subprojects dealt with the design and analysis of powerful codes for various settings. For instance, one aspect focused on subspace codes, which are the appropriate tool for broadcasting information through a network. Constructions of subspace codes with good error-correcting capabilities were derived in this project. Yet another subproject discussed weight distributions of codes over finite ring alphabets. The weight distribution is an invariant that provides crucial information about the error-correcting performance of the code in question. For a variety of weight functions, relations could be derived between codes that share the same weight distribution in a linear fashion, and a correspondence between the weight distribution of a code and its dual could be established in a uniform fashion.

For the various aspects of this project the PI worked with 4 graduate students, two of which have graduated by now and are appointed as assistant professors at liberal arts colleges. All of them have a published paper in a research journal or a paper submitted to such a journal. Training students with respect to studying research articles, approaching research questions, presenting research findings in oral and written form, and time management with respect to teaching and research was and is a core part of the PI's PhD advising. In addition, the PI always strives for the students to have at least one publication by the time they graduate so that they are competitve for the job market. So far, this goal has always been achieved.The PI also worked for one semester with a first-generation undergraduate student on some specific problem arising from this project.This problem, however, turned out to be quite tricky. Despite producing an abundance of examples, only rather limited results could be derived.

Over the period of the project, the PI co-organized various workshops and conference sessions. All of them were closely related to various aspects of this research project and provided graduate students and researchers in postdoctoral positions with the opportunity to become familiar with the best recent work in coding theory and to meet the top experts as well as peers.
